column4:
Introduction

About this course

Note: This programme is only available as a top-up programme and entry is only available to Year 2 upwards.

This course provides the opportunity to investigate the relationship between sport, health and exercise. This is done from the perspective of contemporary society in order to understand the contribution of the public, private and voluntary bodies which support the development of sport and physical activity in the UK. The course is multidisciplinary covering topics that develop a holistic understanding of sport, health and exercise.

The course looks at health and lifestyle, fitness and exercise, how to design training programmes for living a healthy life and for enhancement of sporting activities. This is done primarily from a social science perspective but also includes physiology and anatomy.

In addition research skills are developed to enable the enhancement of best practice and develop in depth understanding of particular areas of interest. To gain practical understanding of the world of sport and leisure, there is a practical work experience at an establishment such as a professional sports club, leisure centre or hospital, working with athletes or professionals as part of a community health project.

What you study
Practical Sporting Activities; Leadership; Psychology; Anatomy; Physiology and Biomechanics; Health & Lifestyle Issues; Nutrition; Leisure Events; Fitness Testing; Sport Policy; Strength and Conditioning; Performance Enhancement; the relationships between Physical activity; Health and Disease; and the role physical activity plays in achieving optimal physical and mental health.

How you learn
The learning opportunities are designed to enhance and develop theoretical knowledge through to skill development and practical application. Traditional lectures, interactive small group tutorials, experiential labs and applied practice, and placement opportunities are all tailored to clearly identified learning outcomes. Private study time is also set aside for each student to enhance their own learning and encourage further development and progression.

How you are assessed
A wide range of assessments take place throughout this degree programme with the emphasis on feedback, development, and progression. Assessment techniques vary according to each module and over the course of study assessments will include: case study, examination, essays, lab reports, class tests, critiques, presentations and practical applications.

Core Themes

You learn how sport has evolved globally, by studying the history of sport and the rise of international sporting movements such as the Olympics and the World Cup. You apply sociological theory to current issues in sport including ethnicity, nationalism, professionalism and media coverage. You investigate the social and practical nature of rule making, sportsmanship, group participation and gender issues.

You evaluate the importance of healthy eating for proper body function and to build muscle. You learn how to produce dietary guidelines which promote healthy eating across a range of people from children to elite performers. Nutrition teaches you how the human body metabolises food (anaerobically and aerobically) and produces energy.

Your studies of the musculo-skeletal system encompass the structure and function of bones, joints, ligaments, and fascia. You apply well known theories such as Newtonâs Laws of Motion to the mechanics and kinetics of human movement to understand how acceleration, force, mass, and momentum affect the human body. You study biomechanics to understand the dynamics of angular motion and how injuries can occur and be prevented. Treatment and rehabilitation of injuries and the physiological and psychological features of the healing process are discussed.

You work in pairs or small groups to carry out practical assignments to measure, test and analyse fitness levels using routine physiological testing techniques. You are encouraged to participate inclusively in each named theme within the programme to acquire specialist knowledge of each, and develop leadership, motivation, communication, decision making and negotiation skills, which are highly regarded by employers. In fourth year you undertake a substantial research project on a topic drawn from your earlier studies.

column3:
Specialist Facilities:

You have access to our Human Performance Laboratory with running, rowing, fitness testing and weights machines. You have opportunities to meet the numerous professional sportsmen and sportswomen who draw on the expertise of our lecturing staff within this facility.

column4:
Career Opportunities:

Directly related job titles include physical activity development officers/coordinators, GP exercise referral consultants, community wellness programmes, fitness consultant, lifestyle manager, sports administrator, and a wide range of jobs within the field of health promotion. You will also find job opportunities in complementary occupations where leadership, motivation and communication are valued â police officer, fire fighter, journalist, marketing executive, public relations officer, youth worker.

MatureIn order to determine an applicant's ability to benefit from study or research at the University of Abertay Dundee, a range of standard and flexible criteria will be used in considering applications.

In most circumstances applications will be considered in light of the following:

Applications from mature students are assessed on the same criteria used for school leavers e.g. SQA Highers or GCE A Levels, where relevant school leaving qualifications exist. For those without standard entry qualifications, consideration is given to experience gained as well as professional qualifications and other forms of learning that could provide evidence of ability to benefit from a particular course.

The successful completion of approved access courses (such as those offered by Dundee College in association with the universities of Abertay, Dundee and St Andrews) provides significant evidence of ability to benefit from study at Abertay.

For further advice please use our Got a Question section.

OverseasThe University makes offers of entry to courses based on qualifications offered worldwide. For undergraduate level entry, if you are studying the International Baccalaureate, you would be expected to achieve at least 26 points. We consider a variety of alternative qualifications on an individual basis. Examples of the qualifications accepted for entry from Overseas students in recent years include: Chinese High School Diploma, Malaysia Advanced Certificate of Education (STPM), European Baccalaureate, West African Senior Secondary School Certificate (WASSCE) with a minimum of 5 passes at B3 or better from external examination plus an accceptable level of pass in JAMB, Indian Secondary Certificate plus Indian Higher Secondary Certificate (10+2), Pakistan Secondary Certificate plus Pakistan Higher Secondary Certificate, Hong Kong Advanced Level Certificate (HKALE).

All applicants are required to provide certified proof of competence in English Language. The University's minimum requirements are IELTS 6.0 (with no band lower than 5.0), TOEFL CBT 223, TOEFL 563, TOEFL IBT 85 or a suitable equivalent qualification.

column4:
Transferable skills

While studying on this course you will gain a number of practical skills that are useful in any field of business, such as how to use email, type reports, build a database and use the internet effectively as well as being introduced to specialised software relevant to your subject choices. You will also learn how to sift through vast quantities of detailed information quickly and to present the important points in a concise and straightforward manner. As you progress through the degree course you will gain other incidental skills which will prove invaluable in any future working environment. These may include:
1. Learning how to learn effectively
2. Self-motivation
3. Assertiveness
4. Time management
5. Meeting deadlines
6. Problem solving
7. Analysis, synthesis, discrimination and judgement
8. Logical and reasoned thinking.

Teamwork

Being able to work as a member of a team is an important quality in a University student. Working in a team situation allows you to utilise your own personal strengths and to build upon areas where you are lacking by learning from other people. It also allows you to gain experience in leading discussions and delegating responsibility, as well as learning to become an effective listener â an important leadership quality which can sometimes be overlooked. Making a positive contribution to a joint project enables you to develop team-working skills.
Working together on coursework often allows you to form close friendships in your social life as you learn to listen to and trust other peopleâs judgements.
